L1.brief_rationale: Foundational concept covering how information is encoded, stored, and retrieved; universally recognized by any student of psychology.
Core cognitive resource that selects which information receives further processing; everyday term with deep scientific content.
The process by which sensory input is interpreted as meaningful experience; foundational to understanding how humans interact with the world.
Broad, familiar concept describing how experience changes knowledge, skills, and behavior over time.
High-profile topic covering general cognitive ability; widely discussed in popular science and everyday life.
Central human capacity for symbolic communication; a major domain of cognitive psychology research.
The mental process of drawing conclusions from premises or evidence; core to logic, problem-solving, and decision-making.
The process of selecting among alternatives; fundamental to cognitive psychology and behavioral economics.
Goal-directed cognitive activity central to everyday function and a classical topic in cognitive psychology.
Affective states that interact closely with cognition; recognized by every student as a basic psychological concept.
Awareness of internal and external experience; a perennial high-level topic bridging philosophy and cognitive science.
The ability to form mental images and ideas not present to the senses; familiar concept with significant research literature.
The loss or failure to retrieve stored information; universally experienced and a central memory research topic.

L2.brief_rationale: The limited-capacity system for temporarily holding and manipulating information; a key term in undergraduate cognitive psychology.
Systematic errors in judgment and reasoning; widely discussed in introductory courses and popular science.
Organized mental frameworks that shape how new information is interpreted and remembered.
Mental shortcuts that simplify decision-making; introduced to students through Kahneman and Tversky's work.
The system storing information over extended periods; a standard distinction in memory models taught at the student level.
Temporary storage of small amounts of information; historically foundational in the modal model of memory.
How thinking, reasoning, and knowledge change across the lifespan; associated with Piaget and introduced in most psychology courses.
The ability to focus on a specific stimulus while ignoring others; a concrete, student-level attention concept.
Internal representations of real or hypothetical situations used for reasoning and prediction.
The idea that category membership is judged by similarity to a typical example; a standard concept in cognitive semantics and psychology.
The tendency to search for and favor information that confirms existing beliefs; one of the most discussed cognitive biases.
Thinking about one's own thought processes; a key term in educational and cognitive psychology.
The influence of prior exposure to a stimulus on responses to a later stimulus; a widely taught implicit memory phenomenon.

L3.brief_rationale: The distinction between fast, automatic System 1 and slow, deliberate System 2 thinking; requires understanding the mechanics of each system.
Craik and Lockhart's finding that deeper semantic encoding produces better memory retention than shallow processing.
The component of Baddeley's working memory model that rehearses verbal and phonological information.
The working memory subsystem that maintains and manipulates visual and spatial information.
The failure to detect changes in a visual scene when they occur during a saccade or visual disruption; demonstrates limits of attention.
Failure to notice an unexpected stimulus in plain sight when attention is directed elsewhere; famously demonstrated by the gorilla experiment.
A model of semantic memory in which activating one concept automatically raises the activation of related concepts in a network.
A framework separating perceptual sensitivity from response bias in detection tasks; fundamental to perception research.
Interference when the color of a word conflicts with its semantic content; a benchmark demonstration of automatic processing.
Judging the likelihood of events by how easily examples come to mind; requires understanding how memory retrieval fluency biases probability estimates.
The ability to rotate mental representations of objects; studied through reaction-time paradigms and revealing of spatial cognition.
The cognitive process of attributing remembered information to its original source; errors here underlie many false memory phenomena.

L4.brief_rationale: Parallel distributed processing frameworks that model cognition as emergent from weighted connections among simple processing units.
The thesis that cognitive processes are deeply shaped by the body and its sensorimotor interactions with the environment.
The proposal that the brain performs probabilistic inference by combining prior beliefs with sensory evidence in a Bayesian framework.
A hierarchical brain model in which top-down predictions are continuously compared to bottom-up sensory signals, with only prediction errors propagated upward.
Brainerd and Reyna's dual-memory framework distinguishing verbatim traces from gist representations, explaining developmental and false memory phenomena.
Sweller's instructional framework positing that learning is constrained by intrinsic, extraneous, and germane demands on working memory capacity.
Memory retrieval is best when encoding processes match retrieval processes, extending levels-of-processing theory with context-specificity.
Anderson's unified cognitive architecture specifying declarative and procedural memory modules with precise timing predictions for human performance.
Baars' theory that consciousness arises when information is broadcast from a central workspace to multiple specialized brain modules.
Loftus's finding that post-event misleading information becomes integrated into the original memory trace, distorting recollection.
The Sapir-Whorf hypothesis that the structure of a language influences its speakers' perception and categorization of reality.
A temporal deficit in detecting a second target appearing 200â€“500 ms after a first target in a rapid serial visual presentation stream, revealing capacity limits of selective attention.
